MEMBERS OF THE BOARD CHARLES W. BRYAN : .....Governor HARRY R. SWANSON i Secretary of State WM. B. PRICE .....L... State Auditor GEORGE E. HALL I State Treasurer WM. H. SMITH I, State Tax Commissioner TAX COMMISSIONERS OF NEBRASKA The position of State Tax Commissioner was created by tbe Consti - tution of 1920. Prior thereto the work was performed by a secretary to the State Board of Equalization and Assessment, the Tax Commissioner being made a member of the board. Those who have served as Commis - sioner under the constitutional provision are: NAME COUNTY SERVED W. H. OSBORNE Custer.. April 25, 1921 to April 18, 1923 WM. H. SMITH Seward April 18, 1923 to Jan. 12, 1925 T. E. WILLIAMS Hamilton.. Jan. 12, 1925 to Jan. 8, 1929 HARRY W. SCOTT Lancaster Jan. 8, 1929 to Dec. 1, 1930 WM. H. SMITH Seward Jan. 8, 1931 to

LETTER OF TUANSMITTAL November 1, 1933. Hon. Charles W. Bryan, Governor of Nebraska, Lincoln, Nebraska. My Dear Governor: Herewith is submitted to you the annual report of the State Board of Equalization and Assessment and State Tax Commissioner, for the year 1933. Shown therein is a tabulation of the abstracts of assessment, as returned by the county assessors of the State, tabulations showing railroad assessments and apportionments, franchise valuations, and other statistical data. ' The past year has been one of the most trying to taxing officials, from the precinct assessors to the State Board, m the history of the State. Many perplexing problems have been presented, but I am happy to state that so far as the work of the State Board and this department is concerned, there has been no litigation! over the action taken, and the assessments stand as originally fixed or equalized. I want to thank you and the other members of the Board for your co-operation, and also the county assessors and other taxing authorities m the various counties. Very truly yours, WM. H. SMITH, State Tax Commissioner.

STATE OF NEBRASKA STATEMENT No. 5 Rolling Stock Assessment The rolling stock assessment of the various railroads is made by the State Board of Equalization and Assessment in accordance with Section 77-616, Compiled Statutes of Nebraska, for 1929. The amount so found is divided by the total number of miles, giving the total valu - ation per mile, and this amount is multiplied by the number of miles In each city or village. This amount is then certified to the county clerk to be added to the assessment of terminal property which is made by the local assessor and equalized by the State Board. REPORT OP TAX COMMISSIONER STATEMENT No. 8 State Levy for 1933 RESOLUTION WHEREAS, from the auditor's report it appears that there was appropriated to be paid out of the general fund the sum of $11,012,667.41 for the biennium, one-half of which should be met for the current year, which is $5,506,332.70, and WHEREAS, it appears there was appropriated to be paid out of the general fund the sum of $304,146.98 in emergency and claims ap - propriations which should be met in 1933, making appropriations to be met in 1933 amounting to „ $5,810,480.68 WHEREAS, there will be available from miscellaneous collections for the general fund not otherwise appropriated, the esti - mated sum of $922,721.21 Plus general fund collections from the in - tangible tax, estimated at $120,176.00 $1,042,897.21 $4,767,583.47 Which amount is increased 3.90 per cent in accordance with Section 77-1007 Compiled Statutes of Nebraska for 1929 ;_ $ 185,935.76 Leaving to be raised from the general fund levy $4,953,519.23 The assessed valuation of the tangible property of the state for 1933, as of record in the office of the Tax Commissioner is $2,073,283,250.00, applied to which sum a levy of 2.39 mills will raise „ $4,955,146.96 THEREFORE, be it resolved that the levy for 1933 be as follows: General Fund 2.39 Mills

REPORT OF TAX COMMISSIONER STATEMENT No. 11 MAXIMUM TAX LEVIES Many inquiries come to the Tax Commissioner for information con - cerning the maximum tax levies that may be made. The following statement has therefore been compiled, containing the information referred to. Special levies such as paving, irrigation, bond, etc., arc not included. The citations to the Compiled Statutes for 1929 were as - sembled by Hon. George W. Ayres, Assistant Attorney General. STATE There is no constitutional limitation upon the amounts the Legis - lature may appropriate although there is some limitation upon the pur - poses for which the appropriations may be made. The State Board of Equalization and Assessment is authorized to levy sufficient tax to meet the appropriations made by the Legislature and in addition thereto a levy of not to exceed two-tenths of one mill on the dollar for the purpose of paying off registered warrants outstanding against the general fund of the state. (See Sec. 77-1007). COUNTIES The constitution limits the amount of tax that may be levied by pounty authorities without authorization by a vote of the electors of pie county to fifty cents per one hundred dollars actual valuation as determined by the assessment rolls. See Section 5 of Article VIII of the Constitution. The power of a county board to levy taxes is further limited by statute to thirty-five cents per hundred dollars on the actual valuation as determined by the assessment rolls in counties having over thirty - five hundred' population. In counties having a population of thirty - five hundred or less the county board may levy not to exceed fifty cents per hundred dollars valuation 'as determined by the assessment rolls. (See Sec. 77-1801). The levy for ordinary county revenue including the support of the poor is limited by statute to not more than three mills on the dollar valuation. (See Sec. 77-1801). TOWNSHIPS The aggregate maximum levy for township purposes is three mills on the dollar of the actual valuation. (See Sec. 26-259). CITIES AND VILLAGES The maximum amount which may be assessed and collected in a city of the first class having from 5,000 to 25,000 inhabitants to de - fray its general incidental and all other municipal expenses in addition to, special assessments and special taxes, is eighteen mills. (See Sec. 16-702). See Note.*

STATE OF NEBRASKA Cities of the second class and villages can not levy taxes for gen - eral revenue purposes to exceed five mills. (See Sec. 17-129 and 77 - 1201). SCHOOLS The aggregate school tax levied for general school purposes Jn school districts organized under Articles 3 and 6 of the School Law- Crural and village schools) shall not exceed eight mills on the dollar of the actual valuation of the district unless a greater levy which can not, however, exceed twenty mills, has been authorized by a vote of the electors of the district. In addition to the tax for general school purposes, a tax of not exceeding two mills per annum can be levied for building purposes if the levy of such a tax is voted by the electors of the district. (See Sec. 79-213 and 79-216). In city school districts the levy for general school purposes can not exceed twenty mills per annum. (See Sec. 79-2523). In the school district of Lincoln the aggregate amount of the school tax levied for all purposes in any one year can not exceed IS mills which, however, may be increased by popular vote to 17 mills, unless a greater levy for certain enumerated purposes is authorized by the electors. (See Sec. 79-2621 of C. S. Supp. 1931). In the school district of the city of Omaha the aggregate school tax can not in any one year exceed thirteen mills on the dollar upon the actual value. (See Sec. 79-2722). *NOTE — At the time property was assessed at one-fifth its full actual value, prior to 1921, the maximum levy for cities of this class was 15 mills. When the law was amended to provide for taxation at the full value, a general Statute was passed reducing all levies to one - flftht' which made the maximum city levy three mills. In 1925, the old Statute was amended, increasing the maximum levy from 15 to 18 mills, the general Statute providing for the reduc - tion to three mills being disregarded, doubtless through an oversight. The amended Statute apparently should have provided for a maximum levy of 3.6 mills.
